CoreOS components of the system support automated management through monitoring of accounts and system activity by logging of related information.
While CoreOS can generate audit data, and securely transport the data to a SIEM, CoreOS does not provide automated mechanisms (e.g. email, text messages) after system events. This functionality would fall to third party software, and therefore, this control is partial, and will only be partially satisfied when implemented by third party software such as an Identity Provider (IdP), Active Directory (MSAD), LDAP, etc.
The ability to use Ignition scripts to configure CoreOS to add local users means that this control needs to be addressed for the case that a local user was added.
See https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-199 for local user account handling in CoreOS.

CoreOS does not have the capability to create guest/anonymous accounts or temporary accounts. Any external emergency or temporary accounts will be inherited from, and managed by, an external identity service (e.g. LDAP).
The ability to use Ignition scripts to configure CoreOS to add local users means that this control needs to be addressed for the case that a local user was added.
See https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-200 for local user account handling in CoreOS.

CoreOS end-user account management is inherited from the hosting environment. Automatic disabling of these accounts must happen at the centralized account management level; for example, within LDAP, Red Hat IdM, or Active Directory.
The ability to use Ignition scripts to configure CoreOS to add local users means that this control needs to be addressed for the case that a local user was added.
See https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-201 for local user account handling in CoreOS.

To meet FISMA requirements, CoreOS must be configured to use centralized authentication (e.g. LDAP, Red Hat IdM, Active Directory). The audit of account creation, modification, enabling, disabling, and removal actions is the respinsibility of the centralized service. Additionally, notification of organization-defined personnel or roles is also the responsibility of the centralized authentication service.
The ability to use Ignition scripts to configure CoreOS to add local users means that this control needs to be addressed for the case that a local user was added.
See https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-202 for local user account handling in CoreOS.

Establishing and administering privileged user accounts in accordance with a role-based access scheme that organizes allowed information system access and privileges into roles is an organizational control outside the scope of OpenShift
However to facilitate a control response, using Role Based Access Control (RBAC), OpenShift roles can be used to grant various levels of access both cluster-wide as well as at the project scope. Users and groups can be associated with, or bound to, multiple roles at the same time.
For service accounts that might also have privileged access, Security Context Constraints (SCC) should be used to limit privileged actions in service accounts.
For the cluster, the kubeadmin user should be completely disabled.
More information on RBAC can be viewed at: https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/authentication/using-rbac.html
More information for SCC can be viewed at: https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/authentication/managing-security-context-constraints.html

This control is applicable to the identity service provider and outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

CoreOS does not have the concept of group accounts.
Should the organization allow shared credentials, the creation and management of such accounts would be the responsibility of the shared identity service and not CoreOS.

CoreOS utilizes the firewall technology embedded into the distribution. This technology, named firewalld, allows a system administrator to configure host-based rules which take effect immediately. This gives an CoreOS operator the ability to immediately drop all remote connections.
Additionally, CoreOS nodes may be placed into Maintenance Mode. This designation will migrate applications from a given cluster node to another, disconnecting any active sessions to a given cluster node.
If immediate disconnect of all hosted applications are desired, individual containers may be halted. This will disconnect user sessions for tenant applications immediately.

CoreOS was designed to satisfy the audit requirements outlined in the Configuration Annex to the Protection Profile for General Purpose Operating Systems available at https://www.niap-ccevs.org/Profile/PP.cfm.
Specifically, the minimum auditable events included:
| Configuration Action | CNSSI 1253 Value or DoD-specific Value | NIAP Reference | | Audit All Logons (Success/Failure) and Logoffs (Successful) | Authentication events: (1) Logons (Success/Failure); (2) Logoffs (Success) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit File and Object Events (Unsuccessful) | File and Objects events: (1) Create (Success/Failure); (2) Access (Success/Failure); (3) Delete (Success/Failure); (4) Modify (Success/Failure); (5) Permission Modification (Success/Failure); (6) Ownership Modification (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit User and Group Management Events (Success/Failure) | User and Group Management events: (1) User add, delete, modify, disable, enable (Success/Failure); (2) Group/Role add, delete, modify (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit Privilege or Role Escalation Events (Success/Failure) | Privilege/Role escalation (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit All Audit and Log Data Accesses (Success/Failure) | Audit and log data access (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit Cryptographic Verification of Software (Success/Failure) | - | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit Program Initiations (Success/Failure) | Application (e.g., Firefox, Internet Explorer, MS Office Suite, etc.) initialization (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit System Reboot, Restart, and Shutdown Events (Success/Failure) | System reboot, restart and shutdown (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit Kernel Module Loading and Unloading Events (Success/Failure) | - | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
Additionally, CoreOS was designed to satisfy the audit requirements outlined in Intelligence Community Standard Number 500-27, "Collection and Sharing of Audit Data" (ICS 500-27) that were found to be applicable to operating systems performing as a container host. A copy of ICS 500-27 can be found at https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/FOIA/DF-2016-00213.pdf
Selected audit events from ICS 500-27 include: * Authentication events * Logons (Success/Failure) * Logoffs (Success) * File & Object Events * Create (Success/Failure) * Access (Success/Failure) * Delete (Success/Failure) * Modify (Success/Failure) * Permission Modifications (Success/Failure) * Ownership Modifications (Success/Failure) * User & Group Management events * User add, delete, modify, suspend, lock (Success/Failure) * Group/Role add, delete, modify (Success/Failure) * Use of Privileged/Special Rights events * Security or audit policy changes (Success/Failure) * Configuration changes (Success/Failure) * Admin or root-level access (Success/Failure) * Privilege/Role escalation (Success/Failure) * Audit and log data accesses (Success/Failure) * System Reboot, Restart & Shutdown (Success/Failure) * Application (e.g. Netscape, IE, Lotus Notes, etc) initialization (Success/Failure)
Coordinating the security audit function with other organizational entities is outside the scope of system configuration.

Red Hat did not express judgement in the rationale for why auditable events are deemed to be adequate to support after-the-fact investigations of security incidents.
For rationale regarding why the auditable events are deemed to be adequate to support after-the-fact investigations of security incidents, please contact your countries Common Criteria representative:
https://www.commoncriteriaportal.org/ccra/members/

Determination of which events are to be audited within CoreOS from the subset of auditable events defined in AU-2(a) is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration guidance.
Should system operators decide to use the NIST National Checklist for OpenShift 4.x, all events identified in AU-2(c) are selected to be audited.
Additionally, in regards to the AU-2(d) requirement of defining "the frequency" of auditing for each identified event, it should be noted that the CoreOS audit subsystem generates audit events in realtime (e.g. immediately upon an audited event occuring).
Organizational review and updates to the audited events are outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

AU-3 is satisfied when the following configuration checks have been implemented: * CCE-82463-1: Enable auditd Service
These configuration checks are enabled in the NIST National Checklist for OpenShift 4.x.

By default, CoreOS auditing uses the internal system clocks to generate time stamps for audit records. At the code level, this is accomplished through the use of the C programming language time.h which is part of the C Standard Library.

By default, the CoreOS auditing records time stamps for audit records that can be mapped to Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). For example in the following node audit record:
type=SYSCALL msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287): arch=c000003e syscall=2 success=no exit=-13 a0=7fffd19c5592 a1=0 a2=7fffd19c4b50 a3=a items=1 ppid=2686 pid=3538 auid=1000 uid=1000 gid=1000 euid=1000 suid=1000 fsuid=1000 egid=1000 sgid=1000 fsgid=1000 tty=pts0 ses=1 comm="cat" exe="/bin/cat" subj=unconfined_u:unconfined_r:unconfined_t:s0-s0:c0.c1023 key="sshd_config" type=CWD msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287): cwd="/home/shadowman" type=PATH msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287): item=0 name="/etc/ssh/sshd_config" inode=409248 dev=fd:00 mode=0100600 ouid=0 ogid=0 rdev=00:00 obj=system_u:object_r:etc_t:s0 nametype=NORMAL cap_fp=none cap_fi=none cap_fe=0 cap_fver=0 type=PROCTITLE msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287) : proctitle=636174002F6574632F7373682F737368645F636F6E666967
The msg field records a time stamp and a unique ID of the record in the form audit(time_stamp:ID). Multiple records can share the same time stamp and ID if they were generated as part of the same Audit event. The time stamp is using the Unix time format - seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 1970.
See https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/8/html/security_hardening/auditing-the-system_security-hardening for more example and explanation of auditing.

Configuration management is enforced through Ignition configurations and Operators.
Ignition is the utility that is used by Red Hat Enterprise Linux CoreOS (RHCOS) to manipulate disks during initial configuration, confirming all new machines meet the declared configuration.
Ignition is meant to initialize systems, not change existing systems. After a machine initializes and the kernel is running from the installed system, the Machine Config Operator from the OpenShift Container Platform cluster completes all future machine configuration.
Operators are a method of packaging, deploying, and managing a Kubernetes application. Watching over the CoreOS environment, using its current state to make decisions in real time, the Machine Config Operator (MCO) manages updates and configuration changes to essentially everything between the kernel and kubelet.
For additional information: https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/architecture/architecture-rhcos.html#rhcos-about_architecture-rhcos https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/operators/olm-what-operators-are.html https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/nodes/nodes/nodes-nodes-managing.html https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/installing/install_config/installing-customizing.html

In OpenShift, the logs depend greatly on the component. Some components would just write messages to stdout that the cluster administrator can retrieve logs through the use of the `oc` command. Some components emit events, and others emit a Prometheus metric which the API server would write into their logs.
For the OCP components that run in a container (most operators), the usual RBAC rules would prevent a non-admin user from reading the container logs or events.
For CoreOS, standard unix permissions protect access to logs. CoreOS error message handling is designed to obscure or not log sensitive information such as passwords, credit card numbers, social security information, account information, etc.
By default, the API server logs are protected by UNIX permissions and only cluster administrators are allowed access to logs.
